RT @UofT: Virtual 'spotting' could help keep drug users safe during #COVID19, according to researchers from @UofT_dlsph @CAPUDofficial #U
RT @CP24: #BREAKING: U.S. to export 60 million doses of AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccine abroad in coming month: AP sources https://t.co/BOl
Novel tactics are needed as statistics point to an uptick in fatal opioid overdoses in Canada, further worsened by the pandemic. [FULL STORY: https://t.co/ZvhDJwXSNP]
If the spottee overdoses, the spotter will call a neighbour, friend or an ambulance to come and help, says Natalie Kaminski, a research assistant on the project.

Before someone consumes a drug, they call their spotter who will be there with them as they use, says project lead and Prof. Carol Strike. The spotter stays on the line with the spottee for another five to 15 minutes to ensure they are safe or call for help if needed.
With spotting, the spottee consumes their drugs in a safe location like their home and a friend, family member or an acquaintance known as a spottermonitors through a digital method.

DLSPH researchers and @CAPUDofficial are studying a remote supervised-consumption model known as spotting to understand its benefits among people who use drugs. STORY - https://t.co/ZvhDJwXSNP https://t.co/5uVJUrF4Ks

The @UofT_ijb just released another story as part of the Generation Distress series. This story is part of a cross-border investigation into youth mental health with the Toronto Star and IJB. Read the story and the thread. https://t.co/iMhzNPGm4W

. @ihpmeuoft Prof. @sriharanabi who studies burnout in the medical field, says Canadas health care workforce is facing a burnout crisis. This, on top of an already strained system pre-pandemic, is resulting in staffing shortages in every profession https://t.co/UsoOvPRc3M https://t.co/bQUGdyIVph

A new study led by DLSPH alumnae found that the United States is experiencing a rise in vibriosis, an infectious disease caused by cholera-like bacteria, and rising sea temperatures from climate change are likely to blame. (Oct 2019) https://t.co/NCx89HxHPj
